content.raw: We probably want to check if input arguments are NULL. In the case _sdf, if the user send a null pointer, it will probably crash in the next statement.
content.html: We probably want to check if input arguments are NULL. In the case _sdf, if the user send a null pointer, it will probably crash in the next statement.

content.raw: If I understand the code correctly, physicsEngine should never be NULL. More like an assert instead of a warning?
content.html: If I understand the code correctly, physicsEngine should never be NULL. More like an assert instead of a warning?

content.raw: Moving this second if to the first position could save some weird cases where name was already an empty string.
content.html: Moving this second if to the first position could save some weird cases where name was already an empty string.

To void long series of brace brackets (error prone) and indentation levels, sometimes is easier to code in the negative form. In this case:

if (!_sdf->HasElement("physics"))
{
    gzlog << "Empty physics profile name specified in SDF. No profile made "
             << "in PresetManager." << std::endl;
   return;
}
...
783e8c5

content.raw:
Yeah, I almost want to make this an assert because it's very rare that the `PhysicsEngine` object would be null without `this` being null. For reference, `PresetManager` is a member variable of `World`, which also has a member variable `PhysicsEngine`. `PresetManager` has a pointer to that same `PhysicsEngine`. But it could happen (maybe in the future when we allow for the destruction and creation of a `PhysicsEngine` during runtime?)

783e8c5
content.html:
Yeah, I almost want to make this an assert because it's very rare that the PhysicsEngine object would be null without this being null. For reference, PresetManager is a member variable of World, which also has a member variable PhysicsEngine. PresetManager has a pointer to that same PhysicsEngine. But it could happen (maybe in the future when we allow for the destruction and creation of a PhysicsEngine during runtime?)

783e8c5

update.description:
Implementation of the Physics Preset Profile API [design](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/e64787224f59902a986c22f7d20fdb39e24b8764/physics_presets/physics_presets.md).

~~Requires sdformat [PR146](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/146/physics-preset-attributes/diff)~~ merged

This PR adds an API for switching between different physics profiles, specified as physics blocks in SDF.

I also included 2 small fixes the ODEPhysics and SimbodyPhysics to handle exceptions.

A forthcoming PR will implement the command line interface to `PresetManager` ([preview](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/physics_presets_cli)) and the ability to generate SDF from physics profiles.

Known issue(s):

In physics elements with elements of different types, e.g. `test/worlds/presets.world` has `preset1` which has `ode`, `simbody` and `bullet` blocks, `PresetManager` will attempt to set all parameters specified in the profile. An optimization would be to only set parameters for the engine that is specified in the `type` attribute of `physics`. Since this is not currently implemented, the test gives a lot of warnings, such as `[Wrn] [PhysicsEngine.cc:225] SetParam failed for [cfm] in physics engine simbody`.

~~The implementation of `PresetManager` relies on `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`. `SetParam` is not implemented for Simbody, so the functionality of this PR will not work with Simbody. (If/when [PR1473](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1473/) gets merged before this, I will complete the `PresetManager` test to include Simbody.~~ merged and simbody test integrated

~~For all the physics engines, `SetParam` is not fully implemented for certain parameters, so you may receive lots of gzwarnings from the `PhysicsEngine` implementation in gzserver.~~ Fixed by [PR1528](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1528/call-physicsengine-setparam-in-child/diff)
update.title: `PresetManager` for physics library

content.html: yeah, in a lot of other code I've been trying to use the C++11 standard equivalent instead of boost (mutex for example) but I guess I didn't here because it looked inconsistent with the other shared_ptrs in that file. I can do it here and we can have another PR to switch some over later

content.html: Now that we are using C++11 maybe is time to start coding using std::shared_ptr instead of boost. @nkoenig what do you think?

a26c151 for const auto, although irritatingly it creates a code check issue (based on the old definition of auto, I believe):

```
./gazebo/physics/PresetManager.cc:53:  Storage class (static, extern, typedef, etc) should be first.  [build/storage_class] [5]
./gazebo/physics/PresetManager.cc:209:  Storage class (static, extern, typedef, etc) should be first.  [build/storage_class] [5]
```

Can these be ignored?

Implementation of the Physics Preset Profile API [design](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/e64787224f59902a986c22f7d20fdb39e24b8764/physics_presets/physics_presets.md).

~~Requires sdformat [PR146](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/146/physics-preset-attributes/diff)~~ merged

This PR adds an API for switching between different physics profiles, specified as physics blocks in SDF.

I also included 2 small fixes the ODEPhysics and SimbodyPhysics to handle exceptions.

A forthcoming PR will implement the command line interface to `PresetManager` ([preview](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/physics_presets_cli)) and the ability to generate SDF from physics profiles.

Known issue(s):

In physics elements with elements of different types, e.g. `test/worlds/presets.world` has `preset1` which has `ode`, `simbody` and `bullet` blocks, `PresetManager` will attempt to set all parameters specified in the profile. An optimization would be to only set parameters for the engine that is specified in the `type` attribute of `physics`. Since this is not currently implemented, the test gives a lot of warnings, such as `[Wrn] [PhysicsEngine.cc:225] SetParam failed for [cfm] in physics engine simbody`.

~~The implementation of `PresetManager` relies on `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`. `SetParam` is not implemented for Simbody, so the functionality of this PR will not work with Simbody. content.html: PhysicsEngine will already give a warning if SetParam returns false. Is another error message redundant, or is is it better to show where the error was propagated to?

for (const auto profile : this->dataPtr->presetProfiles)

content.raw:
Jose set up a nice code coverage jenkins build that we should start using more frequently. In this case, I'm looking at `PresetManager.cc` which has 78% coverage. That's pretty good, but there a few untested functions that could bring coverage closer to 90%.

[Jenkins coverage build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/clover/)

Consider this optional for this pull request.

Jose set up a nice code coverage jenkins build that we should start using more frequently. In this case, I'm looking at PresetManager.cc which has 78% coverage. That's pretty good, but there a few untested functions that could bring coverage closer to 90%.

Jenkins coverage build

Consider this optional for this pull request.
